summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ Office of the Inspector General agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons employee at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York on August 5, 2021. The interview focuses on prison procedures, documentation, and inmate movements around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death, specifically examining the cases of inmates Efrain Reyes and Fernandez.

events.title: Transfer order for Efrain Reyes
events.description: U.S. Marshals Service emails order the transfer of inmate Efrain Reyes from MCC to a GEO private prison, scheduled for August 9, 2019.

events.title: Transfer of Efrain Reyes
events.description: Inmate Efrain Reyes is pre-removed from MCC at 0838 hours and transferred to a GEO private prison, as indicated by 'WAB' (With All Belongings) on the call-out list.

events.title: Movement of inmate Fernandez
events.description: Inmate Fernandez is moved from the SHU to R&D for placement on a dry cell around 3:00 p.m. following a contraband incident during a visit. The system update for his location was not done immediately.

events.title: System update for Fernandez
events.description: Inmate Fernandez is finally keyed out of the SHU and into R&D in the system at 12:35 a.m., hours after his physical move, potentially causing a count discrepancy.

events.title: OIG Interview at MCC
events.description: DOJ OIG agents conduct a supplemental interview with a BOP employee at the Metropolitan Correctional Center regarding inmate movements and procedures related to the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: The interview is part of the official DOJ OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances.
Procedural details are examined for two inmates: Efrain Reyes (transferred out) and Fernandez (moved to a dry cell after a contraband incident).
A key finding is that the call-out list for the SHU, which would show inmate movements, is not retained; it is created in the Sentry system, deleted daily, and likely not stored beyond 45 days.
The interview reveals potential procedural failures, such as the delayed system update for inmate Fernandez's location, which could lead to 'bad counts' and security issues.
The BOP employee explains the chit system for key accountability and confirms that no one can access the SHU with a key alone; all access is controlled by the control center.
